results.title: Dick's laments 'structural decline' in US golf
results.content:
Golfers are plagued by the fickleness of their swings - shining one round, unravelling the next. Retailers who make money out of selling clubs must wish their problems were as trivial.

The chief executive of Dick's Sporting Goods, one of the biggest retailers of golf gear in America, on Tuesday declared that the retail market for golf is in "structural decline."

Edward Stack told Wall Street analysts:

I think golf from a participation standpoint and how it translates into retail is in a structural decline. We don't see that changing. We don't know when it will flatten out.

Dick's took a $20m charge in its second-quarter results, as it wrote down the value of clubs and other golf equipment and eliminated specialist sales roles in its golf division.

The company said that eliminating golf specialists wouldn't put the retailer at a competitive disadvantage because demand is so weak.

Mr Stack, whose father founded the chain shortly after the end of World War Two, lamented:

We just think that, as much as we all love golf, the business reality is that golf from a business viewpoint is under pressure.

The slump in US golf demand isn't just squeezing Dick's. Last month, Adidas said it would restructure its golf business, TaylorMade, because of sliding demand in the US.

results.title: Global investment banking fees smash past $50bn
results.content:
Global investment banking revenues have already surpassed the $50bn mark this year, the quickest rate since the pre-crisis boom in 2007 according to Dealogic.

The old money-spinning fixed income, currencies and commodity divisions of the big banks may still be languishing in the quantitative easing-induced torpor, but at least "classic" investment banking activities like arranging listings and bond sales, and advising on mergers and acquisitions, are buoyant.

It has taken just 225 days to reach the $50bn milestone, down from 246 days last year and the quickest since the 184 days in 2007, Dealogic notes.

The stock market recovery of the western world has powered investment banking revenues this year, with equity capital markets business accounting for 28 per cent of the total, or $14.1bn. Initial public offering revenues of $4.8bn is the third year-to-date total on record, only beaten by 2000 and 2007.

But M&A is playing its part, as the renewed animal spirits among corporate executive boost advisory fees to $12bn so far this year – following two consecutive year-to-date decreases, Dealogic notes.

JPMorgan is the investment banking winner so far this year, taking down 8.3 per cent of the overall revenues. The US banking behemoth is followed by Goldman Sachs and Bank of America Merrill Lynch, which account for 6.7 per cent and 6.5 per cent respectively.

results.title: Carillion sweetens Balfour Beatty offer
results.content:
Carillion has sweetened its merger proposal for Balfour Beatty, as it renews its push to seal what would be a transformative deal for the UK construction industry.

Carillion said the new offer would give Balfour Beatty shareholders a 58.3 per cent share in a combined company, up from a previously agreed 56.5 per cent. Balfour's investors would also get a cash dividend of 8.5 pence per share, valuing the company at nearly £2.1bn under the revised offer terms.

Carillion's dogged pursuit of a tie-up with Balfour, which would create a construction giant with 80,000 employees, has become embroiled in a war of words in recent days, with Balfour management insisting it has a viable strategy to remain as a standalone company.

Talks between the companies unexpectedly stalled earlier this month after Balfour went public with Carillion's opposition to its already planned sale of US design consultancy Parsons Brinckerhof.

Here's the bullets from Carillion's statemen on Tuesday:

  • 58.268% share for Balfour Beatty shareholders based on the current undiluted ordinary share capital of each of Balfour Beatty and Carillion, as well as a cash dividend (or equivalent) of 8.5 pence per Balfour Beatty share (£59 million in total). This values Balfour Beatty at £2,086 million1

    • Balfour Beatty had previously agreed to a 56.5% share for Balfour Beatty shareholders based on the current undiluted ordinary share capital of each of Balfour Beatty and Carillion, worth £1,886 million

    • Carillion's improved proposal announced today represents a premium of 36% to the 1 month Volume Weighted Average Price prior to 24 July 2014 (the trading day immediately preceding the joint leak announcement)

From its statement on Tuesday:

The Board of Carillion continues to believe in the powerful strategic logic of a merger with Balfour Beatty and that, as a direct result of the merger, the cost-base of the combined group could be reduced by at least £175 million per annum by the end of 2016, that earnings would consequently be significantly enhanced from that year, and that these cost savings would represent a capitalised value of over £1.5 billion before any re-rating.

results.title: GameStop CEO to carry on despite brain tumour
results.content:
Video game retailer GameStop says its chief executive Paul Raines will continue in his role despite unexpected surgery on a brain tumour late last week.

The US company said in a regulatory filing on Tuesday that Mr Raines's travel would be restricted as he underwent a follow-up course of chemotherapy, but this would not interfere with his continued leadership of the company.

It explained:

Late last week Paul Raines, GameStop CEO, underwent unexpected surgery during which a very small, cancerous tumor was identified and successfully removed from an easily accessible part of the brain. Because it was found very early, his doctors have advised him that his prognosis for a full and complete recovery is very good. The next step is for Paul to undergo preventive chemotherapy. Recovery from this process is expected to take about six weeks.

Daniel DeMatteo, executive chairman, said:

Speaking for the Board, we have every confidence in Paul's continued leadership and wish him a speedy recovery. While he recovers, our highly-tenured executive team will ensure that our business continues without interruption.

GameStop shares are trading 0.25 per cent higher at $40.75 in early trading in New York.

results.title: Montag named sole BofA COO in management shift
results.content:
Bank of America's chief executive Brian Moynihan has moved to simplify and strengthen his management team.

Mr Moynihan, 54, has given Wall Street insider Tom Montag sole responsibility as chief operating officer of the banking giant, according to a memo sent to staff and first reported by the Charlotte Observer.

Mr Montag, an ex-Goldman Sachs partner and highest paid senior executive at BofA, is seen as a potential successor to Mr Moynihan, depending on the length of his tenure at the head of the bank, reports the FT's Camilla Hall.

Insiders had criticized the split COO role, which Mr Montag had shared with veteran commercial banker David Darnell, as it allowed for two separate sides of the bank.

The singular title also marks a rehabilitation for Mr Montag, who is best known for an e-mail released by the Senate sub-committee on investigations sent during his time at Goldman where he wrote "Boy that timeberwof [sic] was one shitty deal."

Daniel Sparks, the former head of Goldman's mortgage unit - said at the time that the message referred to the bank's losses rather than the composition of the Timberwolf collateralised debt obligation.

Mr Darnell is moving to become Vice Chairman of BofA as he relocates to Tampa, Florida, with his family, Mr Moynihan wrote in the memo.

The move cleared the way for new promotions. The bank also announced that Dean Athanasia, head of small business banking and Thong Nguyen, head of retail banking will now report directly to Mr Moynihan as members of the management team.

Mr Moynihan's changes come as the bank nears a more than $16bn settlement with the Department of Justice on mortgage-backed securities. As the deal gets done, investors are shifting their focus to how the bank will start driving growth.

results.title: Dollar takes cue from construction rebound
results.content:
What happens to the dollar when US data makes differing noises about the economy on the same day? In this case, it strengthens.

The greenback touched a fresh high for the year against the euro - currently one of the paths of least resistance for the dollar - after a report on Tuesday showed US homebuilding rebounded sharply in July.

Stagnant home sales and residential construction has been a worry for Federal Reserve chairwoman Janet Yellen who voiced her concern to Congress in May.

July's figures, alongside a recent rebound in home sales, will go some way to allaying those anxieties.

And the 15.7 per cent jump in housing starts last month overshadowed the latest snapshot of US inflation, which was tepid and doesn't add any pressure on Ms Yellen to raise interest rates.

With the dollar strengthening in the wake of the housing and inflation data, Alan Rusking, a foreign-exchange strategist at Deutsche Bank, said:

It is interesting to see the euro slide through significant support after this data that could have been read as giving Yellen more time to maintain a dovish line.

The FX view seems to be that the euro with the yen is still the preferred funding currency over the dollar, as US data shows US growth is separating itself from soft Eurozone growth, regardless of contained inflation.

The dollar index - a measure of the greenback against the currencies of its largest trading partners - climbed 0.3 per cent to 81.83.

Against the euro, the dollar strengthened to a new high for the year of $1.3317.

results.title: US homebuilding surges at quickest pace this year
results.content:
That's three encouraging bulletins from the US housing market so far this week and it's only Tuesday.

The pace of building on new homes rebounded in July to its highest level since November, the Commerce Department said.

Housing starts climbed 15.7 per cent to an annual rate of 1.1m. Economists had forecast an 8.1 per cent jump from June, when a plunge in construction in the south of the US dragged the national rate lower.

Housing activity, including homebuilding and sales, has proved a laggard as the wider American economy rebounds from a first-quarter contraction.

Although the pace of US homebuilding has slowed since the recession (it peaked at a 2.3m annual rate in January 2006), some economists argue that America's demographics point to an eventual acceleration as the millennial generation start to buy homes.

Earlier today, Home Depot, the DIY chain reported better than expected second-quarter profits. On Monday, an index of homebuilder confidence climbed to the highest level of 2014.

results.title: US inflation rate slows in July
results.content:
UK inflation rattled the pound on Tuesday, US inflation is unlikely to do the same.

US consumer prices edged 0.1 per cent higher in July after a 0.3 per cent rise in June, the Labor Department said.

That eased the annual rate to 2 per cent from 2.1 per cent, just as economists had forecast.

Dan Greenhaus, a strategist at BTIG, said of the report:

Should remind investors that broad inflation measures are not skyrocketing higher, leaving some room for the Fed as it plots its exit course.

The slowing in the inflation rate last month was due, in part, to a 0.3 per cent decline in energy costs last month. That, though, was offset by a 0.4 per cent rise in food prices.

A broad lack of inflationary pressure has helped give the Federal Reserve leeway to keep interest rates at record low levels even as US job growth has quickened so far this year.

However, the balance between changes in the cost of living and wage growth is coming into greater focus as the central banks, including the Fed and the Bank of England, mull when to raise interest rates for the first time since the financial crisis.

results.title: European ETFs dumped by US investors - Markit
results.content:
US investors have yanked almost $4bn out of Europe-focused ETFs over the past week, but the outflow has been cushioned by domestic European investors, according to Markit.

The data provider has some interesting charts (attached below) showing the divergence of demand for European equities, as measured by buying of US-listed European-exposed ETFs (exchange-traded funds) and Europe-listed European ETFs, which have taken in $4.5bn over the past six months.

in the report Markit analyst Simon Colvin wrote:

In a reversal to what had been one of the most interesting investment stories of the year so far, US investors have been actively trimming their exposure to European exposed funds after gorging on the asset class in the opening six months of the year.

The possible causes for this capital flight may range from the fact that Europe stands to lose more from further Russian sanctions, anaemic European growth and the strengthening dollar,. The only certainty is that a growing portion of American investors think that their assets are better invested outside of Europe, something which wasn't the case six weeks ago.

Interestingly, US investors are least keen on "core" eurozone countries like Germany and France, and non-euro Sweden, while Italy and Spain ETFs in the US have enjoyed net inflows over the past three months (see second chart).

results.title: Smells like Justin Bieber? Not so much at Arden
results.content:
Smells like Justin Bieber isn't working out so well anymore for Elizabeth Arden.

The beauty products company said that "celebrity" fragrances suffered a steeper than expected sales decline in the the fourth quarter, as it reported a net loss of $157m, or $5.24 a share, for the period.

Two of the main culprits? Mr Bieber, the baby-faced teen idol turned badboy, and Taylor Swift, the pop star known for infectious/annoying songs about boys.

Elizabeth Arden has been hit hard in recent quarters amid a decline in the fragrance market, particularly in mass retailers like Walmart, raising questions about the reliability of a business tied to celebrity staying power, particularly in the ever-fickle millenial market.

Revenues plunged by 28 per cent in the three months ended in June, to $192m, a significantly bigger decline than analysts had expected.

In a bid to reassure investors, Elizabeth Arden said on Tuesday that it would continue to focus in 2015 on stabilising the business, as it embarks on a multi-year plan to restore profitability and announced a strategic investment by Rhône Capital.

Said chief executive E. Scott Beattie:

Our primary focus as an organization is to improve performance and restore profitability and return on invested capital to levels consistent with historical results.

In June 2014, we announced the 2014 Improvement Plan, which is expected to result in annualized savings of $27 million to $35 million.

We remain committed to achieving a total of $40 million to $50 million of annualized savings upon full implementation of all of our cost-reduction efforts, and remain confident that we can get back to consistent improvement in quarter over quarter performance.
